column9: (ii) alternative models that make the Moon predominantly out of proto-Earth mantle
column10: and (iii) formation of the Earth and Moon from an isotopically homogeneous disk reservoir. Here we use W isotope systematics of lunar samples to distinguish between these scenarios. We report high-precision <SUP>182</SUP>W data for several low-Ti and high-Ti mare basalts
column11: as well as for Mg-suite sample 77215

Our results demonstrate that there are no resolvable radiogenic <SUP>182</SUP>W variations within the Moon
column15: implying that the Moon differentiated later than 70 Ma after Solar System formation. In addition
column16: we find that samples derived from different lunar sources have indistinguishable <SUP>182</SUP>W excesses
column17: confirming that the Moon is characterized by a small
column18: uniform ∼+26 parts-per-million excess in <SUP>182</SUP>W over the present-day bulk silicate Earth. This <SUP>182</SUP>W excess is most likely caused by disproportional late accretion to the Earth and Moon
column20: the pre-late veneer bulk silicate Earth and the Moon have indistinguishable <SUP>182</SUP>W compositions. Mixing calculations demonstrate that this Earth-Moon <SUP>182</SUP>W similarity is an unlikely outcome of the giant impact
column21: which regardless of the amount of impactor material incorporated into the Moon should have generated a significant <SUP>182</SUP>W excess in the Moon. Consequently

column23: leading to the similar <SUP>182</SUP>W compositions of the pre-late veneer Earth's mantle and the Moon.

column1: 2014E&PSL.390..244B|2014|The origin of water in the primitive Moon as revealed by the lunar highlands samples|Barnes
column14: Sara S.|Earth and Planetary Science Letters|390||244|The recent discoveries of hydrogen (H) bearing species on the lunar surface and in samples derived from the lunar interior have necessitated a paradigm shift in our understanding of the water inventory of the Moon
column15: which was previously considered to be a ‘bone-dry’ planetary body. Most sample-based studies have focused on assessing the water contents of the younger mare basalts and pyroclastic glasses
column16: which are partial-melting products of the lunar mantle. In contrast
column17: little attention has been paid to the inventory and source(s) of water in the lunar highlands rocks which are some of the oldest and most pristine materials available for laboratory investigations
column18: and that have the potential to reveal the original history of water in the Earth-Moon system. Here
column19: we report in-situ measurements of hydroxyl (OH) content and H isotopic composition of the mineral apatite from four lunar highlands samples (two norites
column21: and a granite clast) collected during the Apollo missions. Apart from troctolite in which the measured OH contents in apatite are close to our analytical detection limit and its H isotopic composition appears to be severely compromised by secondary processes
column22: we have measured up to ̃2200 ppm OH in the granite clast with a weighted average δD of ̃ -105±130‰
column23: and up to ̃3400 ppm OH in the two norites (77215 and 78235) with weighted average δD values of -281±49‰ and -27±98‰
column24: respectively. The apatites in the granite clast and the norites are characterised by higher OH contents than have been reported so far for highlands samples
column25: and have H isotopic compositions similar to those of terrestrial materials and some carbonaceous chondrites
column26: providing one of the strongest pieces of evidence yet for a common origin for water in the Earth-Moon system. In addition
column29: in some samples of the earliest-formed lunar crust suggests that either primordial terrestrial water survived the aftermath of the putative impact-origin of the Moon or water was added to the Earth-Moon system by a common source immediately after the accretion of the Moon.

column1: 2005GeCoA..69..775S|2005|Nb/Zr fractionation on the Moon and the search for extinct <SUP>92</SUP>Nb|Schönbächler
column12: Detlef|Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta|69|3|775|A comprehensive Zr isotopic study was conducted on eleven lunar basalts and highland rocks to search for evidence of the extinct nuclide <SUP>92</SUP>Nb
column13: which decays to <SUP>92</SUP>Zr with a half-life of 36 Ma. Internal isochrons were determined for two early highland rocks
column14: 77215 and 60025. No resolvable Zr isotopic variations were detected in this wide range of lunar samples and thus there is no evidence for the former existence of live <SUP>92</SUP>Nb on the Moon. The Nb/Zr ratios of lunar ilmenites and bulk rock samples vary by only a factor of two to three relative to the chondritic Nb/Zr ratio. No evidence for larger Nb/Zr fractionation was found. This limited fractionation and late isotopic closure of the source region prevents the formation of measurable <SUP>92</SUP>Zr anomalies in high-Ti mare basalts. As a consequence
column15: it is not possible to draw conclusions from the <SUP>92</SUP>Nb- <SUP>92</SUP>Zr chronometer about the timing of early lunar differentiation and to constrain the role of ilmenite in the source region of high-Ti mare basalts. However
column16: the fractionation is still sufficient to deduce an upper limit for the initial <SUP>92</SUP>Nb/ <SUP>93</SUP>Nb ratio of the solar system of <5 × 10 <SUP>-4</SUP>.

E.|Earth and Planetary Science Letters|23|3|429|The Apollo 17 astronauts removed four rocks samples to represent each of the lithologies they recognized in the boulder at station 7: sample 77215 from an off-white meter-sized block; sample 77075 from one of the thin dikes that cross the off-white block; 77115 from the blue-gray rock adjacent to the off-white block and apparently continuous with thin dikes that cross the block; sample 77135 of the tan-gray or green-gray vesicular rock adjacent to the blue-gray (77115) rock.
